TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS:  Sandy, mixed, frigid Typic Dystroxerepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Bucking loamy sand, on a north facing slope of 3 percent under a cover of red fir and white fir at 6,700 feet elevation.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise stated.  When described on June 8, 1979, the soil was moist throughout).
O1--2 inches to 0; litter, duff and twigs.  (0 to 2 inches thick)
A11--0 to 6 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) loamy sand, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; many very fine, few fine and medium rots; many very fine interstitial pores; slightly acid (pH 6.5); gradual wavy boundary.  (5 to 10 inches thick)
A12--6 to 11 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) loamy sand, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; weak very fine granular structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; common very fine, few fine and medium roots; ma;ny very fine interstitial pores; slightly acid (pH 6.3); gradual wavy boundary.  (5 to 10 inches thick)
C1--11 to 30 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) loamy sand, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; massive; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few very fine, fine, medium and coarse roots; many very fine interstitial pores; 3 percent pebbles; slightly acid (pH 6.3); gradual wavy boundary.  (11 to 30 inches thick)
C2--30 to 51 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) loamy sand, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; massive; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few medium and coarse roots; many very fine interstitial pores; 3 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles; medium acid (pH 6.0); clear wavy boundary.  (20 to 30 inches thick)
C3r--51 to 56 inches; strongly weathered granitic rock with few roots in fractures 7 to 10 inches apart.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Sierra County, Tahoe National Forest; California; about 0.3 miles north of Hwy 49 on Yuba Pass Road, 30 feet east of road in the NW 1/4 of the NW 1/4, sec. 11, T. 20 N., R. 13 E., MDB&M.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Depth to paralithic contact is typically 40 to 60 inches but ranges from 40 to 76 inches.  The mean annual soil temperature ranges from 40 to 43 degrees F and summer temperature is greater than 47 degrees F.  The soil between the depths of 12 and 38 inches is usually dry in all parts from late July to late September and moist in some or all parts the rest of the year.  Base saturation is 17 to 25 percent and increases with depth.  Gravel content ranges from 5 to 15 percent throughout the soil profile.  The umbric epipedon is 10 to 15 inches thick.
The A horizon has dry color of 10YR 5/3, 5/2, 4/3, 4/2 with moist color of 10YR 3/3, 3/2, 3/1, 2/2.  It is loamy sand or loamy coarse sand.  Reaction is slightly to medium acid.
The C horizon has dry color of 10YR 6/4, 5/3, 5/6, 5/4 and moist color of 10YR 4/4, 4/3, 3/4, 3/3.  Texture and reaction is similar to A horizon.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  This is the Gefo series in the same family and the Haypress series.  Gefo soils have a base saturation within the control section of less than 17 percent.  They also have a mean annual soil temperature of 45 to 47 degrees and are moist in the control section for about 8 or 9 months each year.  They also lack a paralithic contact within 80 inches and have a growing season of less than 100 days.  Haypress soils have a mollic epipedon.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Bucking soils are on mountains and are at elevations of 5,400 to 7,400 feet.  Slopes range from 2 to 75 percent.  The soils formed in material weathered from granitic rock.  The climate is typified by warm dry summers and cold moist winters.  Mean annual precipitation is 50 to 70 inches, much of which falls as snow.  The mean annual temperature is 46 to 48 degrees F, the mean January temperature is 27 degrees F, the mean July temperature is 60 degrees F.  The average frost-free season is 100 to 140 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Cagwin, Chiquito, Fugawee, Goodwin, Trojan, Waca and Windy soils.  Cagwin and Chiquito soils are less than 40 inches to a paralithic contact.  Fugawee and Trojan soils lack an umbric epipedon and have an argillic horizon.  Waca and Windy soils have bulk density less than 0.91 gm/cc and the exchange complex is dominated by amorphous material.  Goodwin soils are loamy-skeletal.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Somewhat excessively drained; slow to rapid runoff; rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Bucking soils are used for wildlife habitat, timber production, recreation, and water supply.  Natural vegetation is mainly white fir, red fir, Jeffrey pine, incense-cedar, whitethorn, pinemat manzanita and snowbrush.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northern part of the Sierra Nevada Range of California.  The soils are not extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE:  Davis, California

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Sierra County (Tahoe National Forest), California, 1981.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Was formerly called Buckingham.
Last revised by the state on 5/81.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
